sect1.title: Connection Adapters
sect1.para: The different interfaces of OpenSCADA can all be accessed using different connection adapters. This ensures a greater portability across different systems and programming languages. Each functional interface (e.g. Data Access) has a programming language specific specification (interface) and a connection specific specification (protocol specification).

So, for example, the DA interface consists of two interfaces in Java. They are called Hive and Connection. The Hive interface is the server side and Connection the client side
The difference between client and server was made in order to let the server aggregate several client connections and, on the other side, reduce the complexity of the client interface.. Also there currently exist two protocol specifications for the DA interface. The first is based in the GMPP protocol, which is a proprietary protocol developed by OpenSCADA. The second is ICE from a company called ZeroC. Both protocols have the specifics but for both we have a mapping for the OpenSCADA DA interface. So in addition to the Java interfaces and the protocol specification there are wrappers around the Java interfaces which map them to the protocol specification. This allows developers of clients and server to focus on the sole implementation of their application since they don not need to care about protocol issues. On the other side if one wants to connect to OpenSCADA using a programming language which is currently not supported by OpenSCADA (and I guess there are lots ;-)) he only needs to focus on implementing the protocol specification.

sect2.title: URI format
sect2.para: OpenSCADA uses the known URI format for connection information. The interpretation of the different components of the URI depend on the connection adapter.
Where interface is the type of interface that the connections describes (e.g. da for DA or ae for AE). And connection is the name of the connection adapter (e.g. net for GMPP or ice for ICE).
primaryTarget and secondaryTarget would normally match to hostname (or IP address) and port number.
The query (parameters) part of the URI is used as connection parameters or connection properties.
In addition, in some cases, the fragment part can be used to add a data item to the URI. This is for example used in the URI format of drag and drop operations of data items.

sect3.title: Connection properties
sect3.para: The following connection properties are supported

row.entry: If set to any value it will enable the Apache Mina logging options and inject a logging handler in the IoSession.

If set to any value it will enable the Apache Mina compression filter.
This option has to be enabled on both server and client! Otherwise communication will not be possible.
The default timeout value in milliseconds for all other (more specific) timeouts.
The timeout in milliseconds when establishing a new connection to a server
The default timeout in milliseconds for each message sent using the GMPP protocol. This may be overridden on a message by message basis when passing a message to the protocol stack.
The time (in milliseconds) after which a ping packet will be sent if no other packet was received during that time.
The number of packets which will be sent in the time of messageTimeout unless overridden by pingDelay and unless no other packets arrive.
The socket implementation to use. See for possible values

Indication whether to turn on the SSL engine or not. All following parameters starting with ssl will be ignored if SSL is disabled.
This option has to be enabled on both server and client! Otherwise communication will not be possible.
Specifies the SSL protocol to use. Must be a supported constant from the Java virtual machine that is being used.
The random number provider used for the SSL context.
The password to the key store located at sslKeyStoreUri
The password to the key store located at sslKeyStoreUri
The password of the certificate to use

The URI to the key store file to use.
If the key store is located in the local file system the prefix file:/ has to be used!

sect3.para: For SSL constant names see Java™ Cryptography Architecture Standard Algorithm Name Documentation or the equivalent documentation of the virtual machine you are using.
